texts.shortText:
Colony a flat sheet suspended a millimeter of two above the substratum, to which it is loosely attached by chitinous filaments. The sheet is composed of a single layer of zooecia that are linked to one another by a network of tubes, giving the colony the appearance of a mesh.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are about 1 mm long and elongate-oval in shape. The sides of each are armed with an obvious palisade of about 7-10 sharp, inwardly-pointing spines. Six tubes emerging from each zooecium link it to adjacent individuals to form a perforated mesh. There are no avicularia.
Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 5 cm across.

Global: South Africa and Southern Ocean.

Local/Regional: Known only from Cape Peninsula.

Fairly common on the surfaces of other encrusting invertebrates and on the undersides of boulders, or on ships hulls, but fragments easily and often broken and lost during sampling. The tubes connecting the zooecia allow them to share resources.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.

Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margin. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction. Embryos are brooded inside reproductive individuals and then released to have a short planktonic life before settling to found new colonies.

Beania minuspina is similar in colony form but has only about 5 much longer marginal spines that meet across the face of each zooecium. It is found only on the Cape Peninsula on red algae. Beania magellanica has a similar colony form but no spines.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 127).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 20).

Souto, J, Nascimento, KB, Reverter-Gil, O & Vieira, LM (2019). Dismantling the Beania magellanica (Busk, 1852) species complex (Bryozoa, Cheilostomata): two new species from European waters. Marine Biodiversity, 49(3), 1505-1518.
